fields.title: Your First Python Program
fields.description: Learn how to write and run your first Python program using print statements
fields.introduction: Welcome to Python! In this lesson, you'll learn how to display text using the print() function - the most basic but essential tool in Python.
fields.example_code:
# This is a comment - Python ignores it
print('Hello, World!')
print('Welcome to Python!')

# You can print numbers too
print(42)
print(3.14)
fields.starter_code:
# Write your first Python program below
# Use print() to display a message

fields.title: Variables and Values
fields.description: Discover how to store and use data with variables
fields.introduction: Variables are like labeled boxes where you can store values. They're fundamental to programming!
fields.example_code:
# Creating variables
name = 'Hero'
health = 100
level = 1

# Using variables
print(name)
print('Health:', health)
print('Level:', level)

# Changing values
level = 2
print('New level:', level)
fields.starter_code:
# Create a variable called 'player_name' and set it to your name
# Then print a greeting using that variable

fields.title: Hello World
fields.description: Write a program that prints 'Hello, World!'
fields.problem_statement: Your first challenge is simple: use the print() function to display the text 'Hello, World!' exactly as shown (including the comma and exclamation mark).

fields.title: Multiple Messages
fields.problem_statement:
Use multiple print() statements to display:
1. 'Welcome to Python!'
2. 'Let's learn together!'
3. 'This is fun!'
fields.starter_code: # Print three messages, one per line

test_cases.expected_output:
Welcome to Python!
Let's learn together!
This is fun!

expected_output.output:
Welcome to Python!
Let's learn together!
This is fun!

fields.title: Create a Character
fields.description: Create variables for a game character
fields.problem_statement:
Create three variables:
- 'name' with value 'Knight'
- 'health' with value 100
- 'damage' with value 25
Then print each variable.
fields.starter_code:
# Create your character variables

# Print the character info

test_cases.description: Should create and print character stats

fields.content: Remember to use the print() function. It looks like: print('your text here')
Make sure to include the comma and exclamation mark: print('Hello, World!')
You need three separate print() statements, one for each message
Variables are created with the = sign. For example: name = 'Knight'
